content.question: What conclusions about school segregation in 1954 can be drawn from the map above?

choices.label: Only the states that made up the old Confederacy still practiced segregation in public schools.
School segregation was a national problem, not one confined to a single region.
Every state in the Union had local laws outlining positions on school segregation.
States with the smallest populations generally supported school segregation.
Northern states were free of segregation of any kind by 1954.

content.answer: School segregation was a national problem, not one confined to a single region.
